review.title: Proximal Operators for Multi-Agent Path Planning
review.abstract: We address the problem of planning collision-free paths for multiple agents using optimization methods known as proximal algorithms. Recently this approach was explored in Bento et al. 2013, which demonstrated its ease of parallelization and decentralization, the speed with which the algorithms generate good quality solutions, and its ability to incorporate different proximal operators, each ensuring that paths satisfy a desired property. Unfortunately, the operators derived only apply to paths in 2D and require that any intermediate waypoints we might want agents to follow be preassigned to specific agents, limiting their range of applicability. In this paper we resolve these limitations. We introduce new operators to deal with agents moving in arbitrary dimensions that are faster to compute than their 2D predecessors and we introduce landmarks, space-time positions that are automatically assigned to the set of agents under different optimality criteria. Finally, we report the performance of the new operators in several numerical experiments.

sections.text: Here we review the formulation of Bento et al. (2013) of route planning as an optimization problem, explain what proximal operators are, and explain their connection to solving this optimization problem. We have p spherical agents in Rd of radius {ri} pi = 1. sections.text: Here we examine the proximal operator in connection with the f-coll function, which ensures that there is no collision between two agents of radius r and r-1, which move between two consecutive breakpoints. We distinguish the variables associated with the two agents, and we distinguish the variables associated with the two breakpoints, thinking of n, n, "n" and n "as associated consensus messages. sections.heading: 4 Landmark proximal operator
sections.text: In this section, we present the concept of landmarks, which, automatically and collectively, produce (i) reference points in spacetime that, as a group, agents should try to visit, (ii) establish a good mapping between these reference points and the agents, and (iii) produce collision-free paths for agents who try to visit the points assigned to them. Points (i) to (ii) are essential if the tasks are to be seen as groups of points to visit (Michael et al.2008). Many works focus on only one of these points or deal with them in isolation. An application where points (i) to (iii) are considered, although separately the problem of using color-changing robots as pixels is considered.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: We have introduced two novel proximal operators that enable the use of proximal algorithms to plan paths for agents in 3D, 4D, etc., and to automatically assign waypoints to agents. Growing interest in coordinating large swarms of quadcopters in formation illustrates, for example, the importance of both extensions. For agents in 2D, our collision operator is significantly faster than its predecessor. In particular, this leads to an implementation of the local planning method of speed-obstacle, which is faster than its implementation in both Alonso-Mora et al. (2013) and Bento et al. (2013). The effects of our work go beyond orbit planning. We are currently working on two more projects that use our results, one relating to the visual tracking of several non-colliding large objects and the other relating to the optimal layout design of layouts, e.g. electronic circuits et al. In the first case, the speed of the new collision-free operator is crucial to achieve a real-time colliximator performance we cannot use for ALximators and we cannot use for second ALximators in WA, although we do not use it for ADM very closely.

sections.heading: Appendix for “Proximal Operators for Multi-Agent Path Planning”
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A A comment on the impact of the assumption of piece-wise linear paths in practice
sections.text: A direct application of the approach of Bento et al. (2013) can lead to very large accelerations at the breakpoints. However, it is not difficult to overcome this obvious limitation in practice. We now explain a way to do this. Firstly, by increasing the number of breakpoints, we can obtain trajectories that are arbitrarily close to smooth trajectories with finite acceleration everywhere. As it is not efficient in practice to work with a very large number of breakpoints, we can keep the number of breakpoints at a reasonable level and increase the effective radius of the robots. This would allow us to pass a polynomial through the breakpoints and obtain smooth trajectories that are never more than the difference between the real robot radii and their effective radii from the piece-wise linear ones. With this approach, we would obtain a series of non-colliding finite acceleration paths.

sections.heading: B An illustration of the two kinds of blocks used by the ADMM/TWA
sections.text: As explained in Section 2, the ADMM / TWA is an iterative scheme that alternates between (i) different estimates of the optimal value of the variables that each function in the target depends on and (ii) generates consensus values from the different estimates that affect the same variable; the blocks that produce the estimates that we call proximal operators and the blocks that generate consensus values that we call consensus operators can be interpreted as messages from the consensus blocks (and send estimates back to them); and the consensus blocks receive only estimates from the proximal operators (and send consensus messages back to the proximal operators); therefore, the ADMM iteration scheme can be interpreted as messages going back and forth along the edges of a split graph. Let's illustrate this. Let's imagine that we want to calculate non-conflicting operators for two agents and that trajectories are parametrized by three breakpoints.

sections.heading: C A comment on our implementation of the TWA
sections.text: The implementation of the TWA requires the calculation of proximal operators and the specification for each iteration of what Derbinsky et al. (2013) designates as outgoing weights, − → ρ, each proximal operator. In the TWA there are also incoming weights, ← − ρ, which correspond to the weights that occur in the definition of all our proximal operators, but whose updating scheme is defined for each iteration (Derbinsky et al. 2013, Section 4.1). For the collision operator and interface operator presented in this paper, we calculate the outgoing weights according to the same principle as in (Bento et al. 2013). Namely, if an operator maps a set of input variables (n1, n2,..., nk) to a set of initial variables (x1, x2,..., xk), we otherwise set ni 6 = xi if ni = xi = 0. In other words, if a variable is linked by the outgoing weight, it should not be altered to the outgoing operator.

referenceMentions.context: (2013), which formulates multi-agent path planning as a large non-convex optimization problem and uses proximal algorithms to solve it. More specifically, the authors use the Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM) and the variant introduced in Derbinsky et al. (2013) called the Three Weight Algorithm (TWA).

A self-contained explanation about proximal algorithms is found in Parikh and Boyd (2013) and a good review on the ADMM is Boyd et al. (2011). In general the ADMM and the TWA are not guaranteed to converge for non-convex problems.

A self-contained explanation about proximal algorithms is found in Parikh and Boyd (2013) and a good review on the ADMM is Boyd et al. (2011). In general the ADMM and the TWA are not guaranteed to converge for non-convex problems. There is some work on solving non-convex problems using proximal algorithms with guarantees (see Udell and Boyd 2014 and references in Parikh and Boyd 2013) but the settings considered are not applicable to the optimization problem at hand. Nonetheless, the empirical results in Bento et al. (2013) are very satisfactory.

(2013) are the proximal operators that enforce no robot-robot collisions and no robot-wall collisions. These operators involve solving a nontrivial problem with an infinite number of constraints and a finite number of variables, also known as a semi-infinite programming problem (SIP). The authors solve this SIP problem only for robots moving in 2D by means of a mechanical analogy, which unfortunately excludes applications in 3D such as those involving fleets of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) or autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs). Another limitation of their work is that it does not allow robots to automatically select waypoint positions from a set of reference positions. This is required, for example, in problems involving robots in formations (Bahceci, Soysal, and Sahin 2003). In Bento et al. (2013), any reference position must be pre-assigned to a specific robot.
The authors also re-implement the local path planning method of Alonso-Mora et al. (2013), based on velocity obstacles (Fiorini and Shiller 1998), by solving an optimization algorithm similar to (1).

This is done, for example, in Fiorini and Shiller (1998) and followup work (Alonso-Mora et al. 2012a; Alonso-Mora et al. 2013). The authors in Bento et al. (2013) solve these small optimization problems using a special case of the no-collision operator we study in Section 3 and show this approach is computationally competitive with the results in Alonso-Mora et al.

This is done, for example, in Fiorini and Shiller (1998) and followup work (Alonso-Mora et al. 2012a; Alonso-Mora et al. 2013). The authors in Bento et al. (2013) solve these small optimization problems using a special case of the no-collision operator we study in Section 3 and show this approach is computationally competitive with the results in Alonso-Mora et al. (2013). Therefore, our results also extend this line of research on local path planning to arbitrary dimensions and improve solving-times even further.

We can optimize over the σ’s by solving a linear assignment problem with cost matrix ω, which can be done, for example, using Hungarian method of Kuhn (1955), using more advanced methods such as those after Goldberg and Tarjan (1988), or using scalable but sub-optimal algorithms as in Bertsekas (1988).

Once an optimal σ∗ is found, the output of the operator can be computed as follows.
(2013), which we denote “OLD.” We run the TWA using OLD on the 2D scenario called “CONF1” in Bento et al. (2013) with p = 8 agents of radius r = 0.

(2013), which we denote “OLD.” We run the TWA using OLD on the 2D scenario called “CONF1” in Bento et al. (2013) with p = 8 agents of radius r = 0.918, equally spaced around a circle of radius R = 3, each required to exchange position with the corresponding antipodal agent (cf. Fig. 1-(a)). While running the TWA using OLD, we record the trace of all n variables input into the OLD operators. We compare the execution speed of OLD and NEW on this trace of inputs, after segmenting the n variables into trivial, easy, or expensive according to §3. For global planning, the distribution of trivial, easy, expensive inputs is {0.814, 0.001, 0.185}. Although the expensive inputs are infrequent, the total wall-clock time that NEW takes to process them is 76 msec compared to 54 msec to process all trivial and easy inputs. By comparison, OLD takes a total time of 551 msec on the expensive inputs and so our new implementation yields an average speedup of 7.25× on the inputs that are most expensive to process. Similarly, we collect the trace of the n variables input into the collision operator when using the local planning method described in Bento et al. (2013) on this same scenario.
In particular, it leads to an implementation of the velocity-obstacle local planning method that is faster than its implementation in both Alonso-Mora et al. (2013) and Bento et al.

In particular, it leads to an implementation of the velocity-obstacle local planning method that is faster than its implementation in both Alonso-Mora et al. (2013) and Bento et al. (2013). The impact of our work goes beyond path planning.

metadata.abstractText: We address the problem of planning collision-free paths for multiple agents using optimization methods known as proximal algorithms. Recently this approach was explored in Bento et al. (2013), which demonstrated its ease of parallelization and decentralization, the speed with which the algorithms generate good quality solutions, and its ability to incorporate different proximal operators, each ensuring that paths satisfy a desired property. Unfortunately, the operators derived only apply to paths in 2D and require that any intermediate waypoints we might want agents to follow be preassigned to specific agents, limiting their range of applicability. In this paper we resolve these limitations. We introduce new operators to deal with agents moving in arbitrary dimensions that are faster to compute than their 2D predecessors and we introduce landmarks, spacetime positions that are automatically assigned to the set of agents under different optimality criteria. Finally, we report the performance of the new operators in several numerical experiments.
